Authors:
Eric A Newberry, Teresa M Jardini, Isael Rubio, Pam D
Roberts, Binoy Babu, Steven T Koike, Hacene Bouzar, Erica M Goss, Jeff B
Jones, Carolee T Bull, Mathews L Paret
Title:
Angular leaf spot of cucurbits is associated with genetically
diverse Pseudomonas syringae strains
Abstract:
Angular leaf spot is the most widespread bacterial disease
of cucurbit crops, and is reported to be caused by Pseudomonas syringae
pv. lachrymans. Conflicting reports concerning the host specificity of
P. syringae pv. lachrymans and lack of molecular analysis has left the
true diversity of populations in the United States unclear. In this
study we collected 27 P. syringae strains over several years from
watermelon, cantaloupe, and squash in Florida, Georgia, and California.
Strains were fluorescent on KingÂ’s medium B agar and displayed the
typical phenotypic and biochemical characteristics of P. syringae.
Pseudomonas syringae pv. lachrymans is a member of genomospecies 2.
However, the genetic profiles obtained through both MLSA (gyrB, rpoD,
gapA, gltA) and BOX-PCR (BOXA1R) identified 26 of the P. syringae
strains to be distributed among three clades within genomospecies 1, and
phylogenetically distinct from genomospecies 2 member P. syringae pv.
lachrymans. The identification of a novel multilocus haplotype of the
pathogen common to all states and cucurbit hosts sampled suggests the
potential dispersion of the pathogen through seed. Considerable genetic
diversity among P. syringae strains infecting cucurbits is associated
with the same disease, and reflects the larger ecological diversity of
P. syringae populations from genomospecies 1.
